budget.translation[0].definitions[0].def: the money that is available to an organization or person, or a plan of how it will be spent
budget.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: We had a really tight budget.
a welfare program with a budget of $2 million
The budget for photography has been cut.
The project was completed within budget.
If you come in under budget, everyone will be very impressed.
Feature movies always run over budget.
budget.translation[0].definitions[1].def: an official statement that a government makes about how much it intends to spend and what taxes will be necessary
budget.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The organization has an annual budget of $24 million.
He has a plan to balance the federal budget.
We had to make cuts in the defence budget.
Often the husband and wife contribute equally to the family budget.
The club does not have a large budget for new players.
It was a project with a low budget.
Most young people have to live within a tight budget.
Our clients usually have a fixed budget.
The film had been made on a shoestring budget.
The National Institute of Health had a total budget of $11. 3 billion.
There has been an increase in the overall budget made available by the Government for training.
Hospital caterers have a budget of about £20 per person per week.
The Metropolitan Police has overspent its budget by £70 million.
Further cuts are needed in order to keep within the budget.
the importance of balancing the budget and cutting taxes
The country has a budget deficit of over $4 billion.
A huge budget surplus of over £16 billion was recorded.
The department has suffered severe budget cuts.
budget.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to carefully plan and control how much money you spend and what you will buy with it
budget.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: We’ll have to budget more carefully.
This scheme enables you to budget the cost through fixed monthly payments.
We’ve budgeted for a new car next year.
budget.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if you budget something such as time, you decide how much of it you will need
budget.translation[2].definitions[0].def: very low in price – often used in advertisements
budget.translation[3].definitions[0].def: in the UK, a plan for how the government will collect all the money it needs, which is announced each year by the Chancellor of the Exchequer (=the minister in charge of financial matters). The Chancellor is always shown going to Parliament carrying a special red case that contains the Budget speech. The speech is broadcast on television and radio, and most people take an interest in the effects of the Budget on taxes and on the price of things like petrol, alcohol, and cigarettes.
budget.translation[4].definitions[0].def: an official statement that a government makes about how much it intends to spend and what the rates of taxes will be for the next year or six months
budget.translation[4].definitions[0].exa: There is a great deal in the Budget to help investment.
This year’s Budget is expected to include measures to help small businesses.
budget.translation[5].definitions[0].def: a detailed plan made by an organization or a government of how much it will receive as income over a particular period of time, and how much it will spend, what it will spend the money on etc
budget.translation[5].definitions[0].exa: Each year business managers draw up a budget and suggest a series of financial targets.
The President has promised to balance the government’s budget (=make sure that no more is spent than is received as income) within three years.
budget.translation[5].definitions[1].def: the amount of money that an organization has to spend on a particular activity in a given period of time, usually a year
budget.translation[5].definitions[1].exa: Hospital caterers have a budget of about £10 per person per week.
The service operates on a very tight budget (=with very little money to spare).
The film was made on a shoestring budget (=a very small budget).
budget.translation[5].definitions[2].def: if you are on a budget, you have to do something with as little money as possible
budget.translation[5].definitions[2].exa: Our self catering apartments are popular with those on a budget.
budget.translation[6].definitions[0].def: to carefully plan and control how much you spend
budget.translation[6].definitions[0].exa: $100 million has been budgeted for fees and expenses.
